item.title: Trump, in an Escalation, Calls for Republicans to ‘Nationalize’ Elections
item.description: The comments, made on a conservative podcast, follow a string of moves from his administration to try to exert more control over American elections.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has long been fixated on the false claim that voter fraud is rampant in the United States.

item.title: Trump Is Said to Have Dropped Demand for Cash From Harvard
item.description: Hours after The Times reported that President Trump had lowered the bar for a deal, he denied backtracking and made new threats against Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard has faced internal pressure for months from faculty, students and alumni who view President Trump as an authoritarian and any deal as an act of capitulation.

item.title: Gabbard Arranges Trump Call With FBI Agents After Georgia Election Center Search
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, brokered the call and President Trump directly questioned frontline agents on the inquiry, The Times has learned.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum, Devlin Barrett and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Georgia Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election)
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director of national intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, wearing a coat and dark cap, at the Fulton County elections office in Fairburn, Ga., last week.

item.title: Pirro Threatens Jail Time for Lawful Gun Owners Who Travel to D.C. With Firearms
item.description: The remarks by Jeannine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, prompted swift pushback from the Republican Party’s pro-Second Amendment wing.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeanine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, in November.

item.title: Clintons Capitulate on House Epstein Inquiry, Agreeing to Testify
item.description: Former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the ex-secretary of state, agreed to depositions they had long resisted days before the House was to vote to hold them in contempt.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ricky Carioti
item.media:description: Lawyers for former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, made an offer for Mr. Clinton to testify before the House Oversight Committee after initially refusing.

item.title: N.F.L. Says It Will Look Into Steve Tisch’s Ties to Epstein
item.description: Recently released emails reveal that Jeffrey Epstein sought to connect Mr. Tisch, whose family is a part-owner of the New York Giants, with multiple women.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Matthew Stockman/Getty Images
item.media:description: Steve Tisch said in a statement that he’d had a “brief association” with Jeffrey Epstein that he deeply regretted.

item.title: Epstein Victims Ask Judge to Shut D.O.J. Website After Names Disclosed
item.description: A judge will hold a hearing on Wednesday after attorneys for victims in the Epstein case said the recent batch of documents released by the government included their names.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
item.media:description: Lawyers for victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case say the Department of Justice failed thousands of times to properly redact the names of their clients in the latest release of documents.

item.title: Peter Attia, CBS News Contributor, ‘Ashamed’ After Epstein Files Made Public
item.description: The longevity influencer said he “never witnessed illegal behavior” but would not defend his crude remarks about women and comments on Jeffrey Epstein’s “outrageous” life.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Immigration Officers in Minneapolis Will Wear Body Cameras, Noem Says
item.description: The change comes as the federal government has provided accounts of fatal shootings that have sometimes conflicted with local officials and witness videos.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents and a protester in a confrontation in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump Administration From Ending TPS for Haitians
item.description: The ruling pauses the Trump administration’s plan to end a program that has allowed more than 350,000 people from Haiti to remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Haitian family received help obtaining passports and documents at the St. Vincent de Paul center in Springfield, Ohio, last month.

item.title: Trump Says He’s Only Renovating the Kennedy Center
item.description: Even though President Trump held a movie premiere for his wife’s new film there last week, he said the state of the building was “actually sort of dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Julia Jacobs and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement raised questions about whether President Trump has the power to unilaterally shut down and renovate the Kennedy Center.

item.title: From ‘Hamilton’ to Issa Rae to Philip Glass: Here’s a List of Kennedy Center Cancellations
item.description: More than two dozen musicians, dancers, theater companies and other creative groups have pulled out of performing at the Kennedy Center since President Trump returned to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Presses House G.O.P. to Back Deal to Reopen Government
item.description: Some hard-line House Republicans have balked at the deal Senate Democrats struck with President Trump to fund the government, complicating its path to enactment.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson will be able to afford just one defection on any party-line vote if all members are present.

item.title: Trump Administration Sued Over Cutting Off Funds for $16 Billion Tunnel
item.description: The Gateway Development Commission said that if the federal government continued to withhold funding for a rail link under the Hudson River, it would have to stop construction this week.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: New York City’s First Real Winter in a Long Time Is Relentless
item.description: Mountains of rock-solid filthy snow. Narrow, icy sidewalks. Temperatures that sound like shoe sizes. When will it end?
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart

item.title: Frigid Temperatures Forecast to Continue this Week
item.description: Arctic air will chill much of the United States, but New York’s streak of consecutive freezing days ended on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lisa Zavos bundles up against the cold weather as she visits the beach on Sunday in Miami Beach, Fla. South Florida reached the mid-30s overnight as an Arctic chill moved through the area.

item.title: ‘Today’ Anchor Savannah Guthrie’s Mother Is Missing, Authorities Say
item.description: Savannah Guthrie’s mother, Nancy, 84, was last seen on Saturday near her home in Tucson, Ariz. A sheriff said on Monday that investigators were treating her disappearance as a crime.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Nathan Congleton/NBC, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Savannah Guthrie and her mother, Nancy Guthrie, on the “Today” show set in 2023.

item.title: Mayor Mamdani and the Taxi Driver
item.description: Richard Chow befriended Zohran Mamdani five years ago and has driven him to City Hall and Gracie Mansion.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times

item.title: Attempt to Drill Through Thwaites Glacier Is Foiled
item.description: Scientists lost their instruments within Antarctica’s most dangerously unstable glacier, though not before getting a glimpse at the warming waters underneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Threading a cable through the Thwaites glacier in an attempt to place monitoring equipment.

item.title: The Long Game Behind Xi Jinping’s P.L.A. Purge
item.description: His sweeping military shake-up may look like weakness but it’s clearing the way for a more dangerous force under his full control.
item.dc:creator: John Garnaut
item.media:credit: Luong Thai Linh/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: How a Conservative Texas District Rejected the Politics of Division
item.description: Many Americans are growing both exhausted and frightened by Trump’s scorched-earth, hyperpartisan, fire-ready-aim approach to the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Talked to Agents Investigating Election Claims
item.description: Also, the Supreme Court secretly made itself even more secretive. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Woodie King Jr., Impresario of Black Theater, Dies at 88
item.description: His New Federal Theater in New York provided a rare stage for Black playwrights and emerging actors, among them Denzel Washington, Phylicia Rashad and Chadwick Boseman.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf (Play)
item.media:credit: Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Woodie King Jr. in 2004 in front of the New Federal Theater in the Henry Street Playhouse building on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

item.title: Woman’s Dismembered Body Is Found in a Brooklyn Basement, Officials Say
item.description: The police are investigating the death of Michelle Montgomery, whose remains were found in a public housing building in the Williamsburg neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan and Sean Piccoli
item.category: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of Michelle Montgomery, 39, were found in the basement of a building in the Borinquen Public Houses complex on Bushwick Avenue on Sunday morning, the police said.

item.title: Elon Musk Merges SpaceX With His A.I. Start-Up xAI
item.description: The deal further intermingles Mr. Musk’s companies and creates the most valuable private company on earth.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s rocket facility in Boca Chica, Texas.

item.title: Third Candidate Enters Heated Race for Open House Seat
item.description: Julie Won, a New York City councilwoman, will face two other Democrats, one backed by the departing incumbent, Nydia Velázquez, and the other by Mayor Zohran Mamdani.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julie Won, a New York City councilwoman, immigrated to New York City from South Korea at the age of 8.
